editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: Lawtrickes or, who would have thought it.
As it hath been divers times acted by the children of the revels.
London printed for Richard more, and are to be sold at his shop in s. Dunstanes Church-yard in Fleetstreet. 1608.

div.head: The book to the reader.
div.p: Honest reader, by thy patience, this is the first time of our meeting, and it may be the last, that's as we shall agree at parting, wilt buy me, the stationer thanks thee; wilt read me, do: but pick no more out of me, than he that writ put into me: nor know me not better than he that made me: such mechanic gods this hill of Parnassus harbours: we have a strange sect of upstart physiognomers, grown up amongst us of late, that will assume out of the depth of their knowings, to calculate a man's intent by the colour of his complexion: nay, which is miraculous, by the character of his report ▪ and 'tis wonderful to consider: cannot an honest man speak to a knave, but his language must needs be scanned? A gallant to a countryman, must his intent be to rob? must a cuckold of consequent necessity dwell at the hartshorn? and a musician at the cat and the fiddle? strange interpretations. I say no more, but if the cobbler would look no further than the shoe-latchet, we should not have so many corrupt translations: for mine own part I reverence all modest advertisements, and submit myself to any judicious censurer, and protesting I never held my irregular course, but my ink hath been always simple, without the juice of wormwood, and my pen smooth without teeth, and so it shall continue.
Thine or any man's for a testar.

div.head: Law-tricks, or who would have thought it.
Actʋs primus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Divine invention, oh how I could hug,
And like an amorous lover court thy beauty,
That crown'st me King of pleasures! were my brain
Forged out of vulgar metal without fire,
And sprightly motion, my big-swollen hopes,
Had been stillborn, but when dejected minds,
Out slept the golden pleasure of the night:
My serious meditations have outwatched,
The glorious tapers that attend the moon:
I turned my thoughts into a thousand shapes:
Moulded the fashion of ten thousand plots,
Liked and disliked so many, that my brain
The mother of invention grew barren,
Almost passed bearing, still my laboring thoughts
Conceived a yet more strange and quaint idea,
Gave it proportion, and I brought it forth:
And that blessed infant of invention
Beyond all hope hath my contentment won,
And that's love's heaven I love a face more fair
Than Cinthia's as hue that seems above compare,
but hell, her husband with a jealous eye
Ushers her steps, o wedded slavery!
This tender rose, whom artless marriage,
Hath grafted on a nettle (Testy age)
Have I ungrafted, made himself untie
The knot of wedlock: thanks sweet industry.
And here 'a comes, that which most heaps my fame,
His wit's well spoken of.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This wit's a sprightly thing ▪

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: For such as have't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It not alone doth bring,
Public applause, but knowledge i'the law ▪
Teacheth to speak in distance.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: How the daw
Scours o'er his rusty phrases? honoured count,
How grows your plot?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My thriving fortunes mount
Above suppose, even to my heart's content:
We are divorced.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My hopes are prevalent.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You know the cause on't, two sufficient men
Swore her a harlot, and the partial bench
Inspired by my good angels (Angels wings
Sweep a clear passage to the seat of Kings)
Sealed our divorce.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: But doth her brother swallow
This gross abuse?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Abuse, away, away.
They know me rich Horatio, chink, chink:
Whilst this holds out ▪ my cause shall never sink.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: See where 'a comes, his sad complexion wears,
Griefs mourning livery, he is clothed in tears.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Whence springs this sorrow?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For my sister's shame,
My sister, o my sister, whose repute
Hung like a jewel on her sex's forehead.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And what of her?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: She is, oh no she was
Pure as the diamond, clear as crystal glass,
But now, oh hell, her credit is more foul,
Then speckled scandal, or black murders soul.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I cannot think it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But I know't too true,
She was my wife and by her means, my head
Was fairly tupped and you will buy a lantern:
Bespeak my sconce, 'tis ready horned and all.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Not yet, but I'll take order that it shall.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And are ye parted?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What a question's that?
Shall I wear cracked rings, diamonds with a flaw,
I'll carry coals and you will, no horns, I know the law.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Is this your grief?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This is enough, to make
Patience tu●nerussin, she that was the pattern,
To whose proportion all our courtly dames,
Cut out their actions, she to fall●a sign —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: More will fall shortly.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Her shame —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Grows here, whoever broached the wine,
The butt stands here, my forehead bears the sign,

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: It merits none, the shame's nor yours nor his,
That foot's even made that never treads a miss,
Beauty came first from heaven, Prometheus,
Stole it to make proud women bewteous,
Now, stolen goods thrive not: women steal from men
Then blame not them to seek their own again.
King's have for this been felons, and 'tis proved,
He never was divine that never loved.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I find no law for this.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Custom you prove,
And what's more ancient than to pilfer lovet

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A quillet well applied.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Then bury grief,
If this be felony, myself's a thief.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A nimble wit, just of the length of mine.
But come my liege, forget, it so will I,
Our infant griefs must be old men and die,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Not whilst her fault survives,
What news with thee.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I bring your honour comfortable news,
Your son's returned from Pisa,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: 'A comes ill,
And yet I hope his blessed arrive will kill
This monster grief.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: He is a towards prince.

sp.speaker: Fe.
sp.l: Toward enough, and yet most strangely weaned
And wedded from this world's society.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: A parlous youth, sharp and satirical,
Would a but spend some study in the law,
'A would prove a passing subtle barrister.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Has a quick wit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And 'a speaks Latin too,
Truly and so few lawyers use to do.

div.stage: Enter prince Polymetes with a book.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Health to this honoured presence: passing good!

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Welcome sweet prince.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: Thanks: superpassing good!
But honoured father, see how he proceeds:
Learning was first made pilot to the world,
And in the chair of contemplation,
Many degrees above the turning clouds
Held in his hand the nine-leafed marble book,
Drawn full of silver lines and golden stars.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But son?

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: But father, it was learning's place,
Till empty outsides, shadows daubed with gold
Plucked him down headlong, then he lost his wits,
And ever since life's zany to the world,
Turns pageant-poet, toiler to the press,
Makes himself cheap ▪ detested, hissed and stale,
To every bubble and dull groom.
Who for his outsides gawdy, will presume
To make poor wit a hackney to his pride.
And with blunt rolled jests spurgall his side
Till his soul bleed, oh, I am more than mad,
To see mere shadows censure and control,
The substance, worthier both in sense and soul

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Fie Polymetes, though the robe of learning,
Sit comely on a prince, yet wean thy thoughts
From this strict contemplation, and embrace
Public assemblies, knightly exercise.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: How's that? to swear and give the sunden stab?
Sell lands to purchase fashions? O 'tis base!
Bought gentry, should trueborn worth disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Practice to hunt.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No, some that use that sport
Give't o'er, being scarce one hair the better for't.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then practise revels.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Revels sprightly play,
Yet every year, some revel all away.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: All these are trivial: prince, be a lawyer:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Of all land monsters, some that bear that name,
Might well be spared, whose vulture avarice
Devours men living: they of all the rest,
Deal most with angels, and yet prove least blessed.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Wrong not the law.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I cannot, 'tis divine:
And I'll compare it to a golden chain,
That links the body of a commonwealth,
Into a firm and formal union.
It holds the sword, with an impartial hand,
Curbs in the reins of an unruly land,
'Tis twined to justice, and with holy zeal,
Rightly determines the poor man's appeal.
And those that are law's true administers,
Are fathers to the wronged, heaven's justicers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fore-god 'tis true, right properties of the law
But under favour, and with due respect
Of that unvalued pearl, and the professors,
Yourself and such lack-latin advocates
Infect the heart, and do their best to change
The true intent of sanctimonious law.
Turn church yards champions, and make the ground grown rank with grandsire's flesh,
Bear corn to feed the son.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Will this be suffered?
But Polymetes, in thy stay at Pisa,
When heardst thou of thy sister?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Much too late,
the reason, with your patience I'll relate.
Beauteous Emilia, whom I never saw,
But in the rhetoric of discursive tongues
In sancta monta, neighbour to Sardinia,
Where silver Arno in her crystal bosom,
Courts the fresh banks with many an amorous kiss.
My sister (As the country custom claimed)
With all the choicest virgins of the land,
Met at the temple ▪ half a league remote,
From all resort of people, which was decked
With all the relics, and the choicest gems,
Marseilles, Pisa, or Leghorn could yield.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What followed this rich preparation?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whilst they securely tend their orisons,
Three armed galleys of the faithless Turks,
At this advantage set their men on shore,
Entered the temple, and profaned their shrines,
On the high altar sacrificed the priests,
Disrayed the temple of the golden robes,
Murdered the matrons, ravished the maids,
And dragging them by the disheveled hair,
Did with their ravished bodies fill their boats,
Amongst the rest, Emilia whom report
Called by no name but only beautiful,
Was ravished, slain, or taken prisoner.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: O Polymetes! thy discourse confounds,
Thou healst old hurts, yet givest us deeper wounds,
But words are air, see our armed galleys maned,
And in them place as many of our knights
As loved Emilia and their sovereign's health.
I'll unto Pisa, and till our return,
Because our widowed dukedom shall not mourn.
Be thou her minion, and possess her chair,
Fill that with honour, 'twill fill thee with care,
Urgeno denials, Genowa's a dew,
we leave old griefs, and go in quest of new.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Better and better, now my hopes are fit,
The Duke thus gone, what tongue so bold dares say
I wronged my wife?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: That dares Horatio's.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou art myself, we both have but one bosom
One tongue, one soul, two bodies and one heart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know't my lord.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: 'Tis true, but let that pass,
We two are one.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know your honour's wise.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And I know thee
For no small fool, 'twas simple policy,
And not without some counsel of the law,
That not withstanding my wife's near alliance
Unto the Duke, I purchased a divorce.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What was the cause?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I tell thee, the most wrong
Was this, my avarice thought she lived too long.
I know one man hath coffined up six wives
Since she was mine, and by the poorest, pursed
A brace of thousand pounds: still good in law,
Men must be rich, by thrift our treasures rise,
Give me the man's knave rich, take you poor wise,
But close, cock sure I'll feed me fat with sport,
Gull all, fooled all, why? I have law-tricks for't.Exit

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How justice Slender glories in the plot,
Which to deceive him, my full brain begotten?
But to his wife, true virtue though disgraced,
She's now half wooed because she's thought unchaste
Her sex's credit, or discredit thrives
In th' outward shape and fashion of their lives,
And be a woman's virtues never so strong.
Her honour's weighed upon discourses tongue.
Be her fame sullied, were her thoughts as bright
as innocence, the world would count her light.
For though amongst women, most are beauteous,
They that please time are counted virtuous,
And in this hope, I'll to the countess go,
She's counted light, love grant I find her so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Welcome to Genea madam, and to make a short cut of our long travel, faith tell me, how do you feel yourself since you came ashore?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Feel myself? why with my hands, what an idle question's that?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Then pray be you better occupied in your answer: but madam, do you remember what a multitude of fishes we saw at sea? and I do wonder how they can all live by one another.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why fool, as men do on the land, the great ones eat up the little ones, but Joculo, I am great, passing great, and ready to lie down.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Do madam, and I'll stand by and do my good will to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Man's death of what?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Why of your maidenhead madam and if you please, or rather of the huge birth of knavery you're in travel of.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And insooth Joculo at this time I stand in some need of a witty midwife: but may I trust thee?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p:
Above the girdlestead, and below the knee madam without any danger, why madam, you know at our first meeting in the Turks galleys, where we were both prisoners, and in a manner strangers, I rested faithful when we counterfeited ourselves lunatic to escape their fury I proved not false when we were cast naked ashore: I stood firm to you, and never since left your company: now having had these trials of me abroad, never
mistrust my secrecy at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I will credit thee, and now receive this embryon of knavery, briefly as I deliver it. I understand since our private arrival here at Genoa, that the Duke my father hearing of my surprisal from monta sancta, attended with a hundred knights, is gone to seek a needle in a bottle of hay.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Or rather to catch a quick eel by the —

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Teeth, as I have done you sir?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Nay, and you break jests a my teeth once, I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: If the breaking of the jest kept your teeth whole, 'twas well broken: but to the purpose; as well to try what mettle our Genoese wits are made of, as also to put my brother's humour to the test, I intend to dance a pretty change with my name (For by nothing else I am sure they can know me, being in my infancy carried to my ants at Pisa) then instead of Emilia, call me Tristella.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Agreed, but what man i'th mist is this?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I know not yet, let's walk, and take occasion to confer with them.

div.stage: Enter Polymetes reading, end Inlis taking tobacco.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Yet keep without eye-shot so long as you can

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: O most divine!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Tobacco? the best in Europe, 't cost me ten crowns an ounce by this vapour.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Art not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Of your foppish humour? yes by this element villanously ashamed, pox on't, leave it, you are a scholar, go but to antiquity, read the chronicles, you may find some of your ancestors chronicled for winning a wench's favour for losing their armour, but few for wit and scholarship: soldiers and
scholars could never set their horses together, especially in this kicking age: but who comes here? one she-satyr or other to pitch up her tent, cast down her gauntlet and proclaim thee coward for not stabbing her, when she gave thee the most plain apparent and open lie.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Joculo, we are fallen into their eyes.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: They'll hardly see their way then, for we are shrewd moats, but all's one, I'll give occasion of quarrel, answer you as you can,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Your reason sir?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: To make thee recoil, or with the soldier to fall off, is't your country manner to corrive a leader, being upon or before present service as I am?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, I did not see your charge.
Would I had never seen her, for her eye
Hath set my thoughts in a strange mutiny.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What, in love Julio?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: No prince, love's in me,
I like a slave endure love's tyranny.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Madam, your brother.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Slave to all slaves be he that snares his eye,
In a weak Siren's cobweb flattery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: God save fair sweet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Amen, from such as you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You had said for such, had your tongue gone true.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why then belike I lie.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I would you did, within my curtains.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Marry love forbid.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Nay, love is willing, for he cries let's go:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then love hath two tongues, for he tells me no,
So pray let's part.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: What, and our lips not meet?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Now fie upon't, like broom-men in the street?
You're a young wooer, or else much too rude,
To show this kindness fore a multitude,
but by the blush that colours o'er your face,
You would scarce do't in a more private place.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: This same strange thing i'th likeness of a woman,
Tastes of much wit, though I not love her sex,
I'll arm my thoughts to crack a jest with her.
What, gravelled Lulio?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, but run a land:
Is your wit's shipping any better manned?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, will you board it?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No, I dare not venture:

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Make but a shot in jest and you may enter.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You are a scholar.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I have seen some schools.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: You came not o'er i' the last fleet of fools.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You took my room up.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I pray take't again,
We'll have no women fools sail amongst men.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Your wit's much currish.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why 't bites not you,
It feeds on fool's flesh, so wise-men adieu

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.p: Please you accept the curtsy of the town?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I need not, I have curtsies of mine owns
There's one for you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How chance your wit's so free?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Only to outgo jadish company.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Here are none such.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Take heed, for if you tire,
She'll keep her pace and leave you in the mire.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: A woman's feature, but a scholar's tongue
In quick discourse, philosophers ne'er wondered
More at the strange conception of the winds,
Than I admire how she attained this wit:
Did not true learning make the soul divine,
She hath spoken enough to make me convertine.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My loves are sound, and wait but your reply,
A short lined accent, either no or I.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I am not too severe, nor yet so kind,
To fall for every idle puff of wind.
But farewell, I'll take counsel of my pillow,
Pity fresh youth should wither in green willow.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Appoint the place sweet, I'll not miss mine houte.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: At the three fools.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'll meet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And make up four.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sweet words, kind looks, what? and a parting kiss.
Words, looks and lips cry all, the wench is his.
I am possessed devil, love persuades my mind,
That if to him, to me she'll prove more kind.
What's Julio made of? hadst thou soul or sense,
Thou wouldst not prentice thy affections,
Nor tie thy fortunes to a stranger's love.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: A little liking my lord, a jerk a trick or so, but no pure love I protest, but be impartial, cast of the furred-gown of hate, and speak out of the naked doublet and hose of judgement: is she not worthy to be beloved? nay, might not she and I live passing well together?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, if to live in bondage be no hell,
I think you two, might do exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Well my lord, because I'll be no example of self-will, I'll break off our meeting at the three fools, and send for her to court, where I'll put all my love into one quart of maligo, and your melancholy humour into another, and he that hath done last, shall for penance give her a kick a the lips, and a pipe of tobacco be my witness, that's all the love I bear her.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Well Julio,
Howe'er you juggle, if you do agree,
You must be pleased to wear the keeper's fee. exennt

div.head: Actus secundus.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Sir, I do not love to double with a woman if my friend, much less with you my most upright and straight count, my young lord (As I told you) is turned absolute prodigal.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: How prodigal?

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Marry thus prodigal, to frequent ordinaries is his ordinary practice, rubs out whole weeks together in bowling. Allies, bandies away his pocket full of french-crownes in a morning, and counts it a pretty sport to procure heat.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou tellst me wonders, he that but last day,
Was never seen to walk without a book,
Writ against pleasure, and make bitter jests
Of honest recreation, turned dissolute,
I see no reason for't, the law and I,
(I tell you plainly Adam) think you lie.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: Think as you will sir, there's not a trick used in the town that deserves damnation, but he desires to deal in't, 'tis pity 'a was not made a tradesman, he loves to follow his occupation a life, and that which makes him doubt most, he is in love with the Indian punk tobacco.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Punk! how the fool that doth not know it slanders a leaf, nicknames a stranger herb.

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p: No herb a grace I hope sir.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nor good thrift neither,
Yet there's one dunce, a kind of plodding poet,
S 〈…〉 Care's 'twas not in the first creation,
Because he finds no ballad argument,
To prove old Adam a tobacconist,

sp.speaker: Adam.
sp.p:
I think none a the name louts it,
I have heard old Adam was an honest man, and a good gardener loved Lettuce well, salads and cabbage reasonable well, yet no tobacco: again, Adam Bell a substantial outlaw, and passing a good archer, yet no tobacconist. Further, Diogenes, whose proper name might be Adam for ought I know, loved carrots well, leek porridge ▪ passing well, yet no tobacco: to conclude, my great grandfathers grandfather's father, and myself all gardeners, yet could not abide this chimney-sweeper tobacco .

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: They did not: take me with you, what's the, cause they were all plain folks, and did not know the laws.

sp.speaker: Adam
sp.p: They were plain indeed, and thereof grew the prover be, plain dealing is a jewel.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: But he that useth it shall die a beggar.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: That addition was made by some lawyer or poet, to avoid which, they cannot endure plain-dealing should have a hand in any of their actions.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Touch no man's function, there are jerks and tricks
Spurn not the law, for if you do, it kicks.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: So will a spur-galled jade sir, but to all these misdemeanours, 'a maintains a private punk, one Tristella that he had in way of reversion from Julio, a twinger, a mere horseleech, one that will suck out the brains of his treasury, and make a mere skin of his wealth, ay, out of my love reprehended his error, and he in a fury kicked me out of doors, and discharged me of his service.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I like not this, 'tis neither right nor straight done with no law-trick, nor no good conceit, but here 'a comes.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: With autumn in his bosom, pray God she shake not down his leaves, and leave him to make the Duke his father a bald reckoning.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Peace and observe.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Though I be a stranger to you,
yet am I well acquainted with your humour.
A lady cannot live about the court
Without the envy of your epigrams,
If she be pleasant, she is counted light,
If ruddy, painted, if her ruffs be thick,
They ask much poking.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Trust me, love hath killed
That wormwood humour, bring th'authority
Of one true tongue to prove my poesy,
Ever wronged woman.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And you'll do't again?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: That's a good wench.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I pray who ought that pen?
That in a stammering iambic vain,
Glanced at Emilia's loose and gaudy train.
And broke broad jests upon her narrow heel,
Poked her rebates, and surveyed her steel,
Tide her fringed garters, bought her words by weight

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Still good in law, and an upright conceit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Do you not know that man?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Suppose I do?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You did but flout them, and you'll flout me too
You wondered not Cornelia being so fair,
Would be beholding to her laundress dress hair.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I know not this.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: True, nor that Florymell,
Became a page's habit passing well,
Used single rapier, took the rouse and swore,
Of all land beasts she could not brook the boar,
Nor that count Lurdo, coming to a fray,
Brought not the worth of one poor hair away.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: More than his own.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: That jest comes near to me,
'Tis overgrown now, 'a wants authority.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Nor that Melina whom your muse renowns
Wore out as many suitors as new gowns.
And the same day that she was married,
Upon her finger wore her maidenhead.
In likeness of a diamond.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Indeed 'twas said,
That for ring Melina sold her head.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: But you're all Ovid's.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: They are bawdy mates,
Touch lawyers too, indeed abuse all states,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Poets are wanton, and no doubt enjoy,
Their fair Corynna's, though perhaps less coy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Suppose some do?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Each one in this agrees to scandal us.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: And talk of lawyer's fees.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Grant me but love, and with my utmost power,
I will defend your sex's stainless honour:
And with my pen dipped in the juice of gall,
Be his soul's terror, that hereafter shall,
Cast ink at honour's garments, or aspire
To name your sex with an unhallowed fire.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I take your word.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: Then seal it with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: That kiss my lord deserves an epigram ▪

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sit down good uncle.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: An unbidden guest
Should bring a stool along.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: A woman's jest.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: You mean a lie, for women use to lie.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: But not like scholars by authority.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yet they may produce lying authority, and so cannot poets,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Nor lawyers neither.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Are you a lawyer?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: I'faith madam, he hath sit on the skirts of law any time this thirty years.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p:
Then he should be a good trencherman by
his profession.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Your reason Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I knew one of that faculty in one term eat up a hole town, church, steeple and all.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: I wonder the bells rung not all in his belly.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: No sir, he sold them to buy his wife a taffety
Gown, and himself a velvet jacket.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: What a proved Jack was that? but I wonder at lawyers for one thing, many of them use to take their fees aforehand.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: For a twofold policy, one is they were commonly greedy, the other for fear if their clients follow their counsel long, they will not be worth a fee.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.p: 'Tis well said lady, you do well to jest with an old man.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: 'A says true, for if you should jest too much with a young man, it might prove earnest, and so the fruits of your jests make you both a shamed on't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well said Adam, but leaving at a full jest, uncle, what earnest business brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Your honour's sudden metamorphosis,
Told by your trusty servant, and confirmed
By public rumor.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Why what says goody fame, and my trusty servant

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This is the worst my lord that you expend
Your treasure on that lady's maintenance.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: 'Sfoot say I do, what, has the worm-eaten bawd fame: or ere a pander-like fool else to do with it? give her maintenance, why she is of my near affinity, should I see my she affinity go in tatters? I allow my servant rags, and I were worse than a Jew, if I should suffer my she affinity to go naked.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Law takes your part, and if your purse grow short
Rather than spend the public treasury,
I'll lend your grace a brace of thousand pounds,
provided this, that as our bookmen write
I have security.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A lawyer right?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Security? Leases and old rends, castle and townships, able men, good security, towns are no starters, they'll hold out wind and weather.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I crave no more, let me have pawns and use.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How? Lords turn usurers? those that should
Punish broke age deal upon pawns?
If it were once his own,
He'd lend him money on his dukedom's crown

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: But faith uncle tell me, what think you of this
Lady? would she not make a pretty pert Duchess?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: She's fair, nor do I discommend your choice
I wish her yours, a private friend or so,
I know mad jerks, and know that law allows,
Princes their private pleasures, and myself
Will do my best to gain your honour's love,
I will not absolutely say there are,
But there may be, if so your honour please,
Sellers and vaults, which from your private garden
May under ground lead to your bedchamber.
Whither, I will not name myself, but some close friend,
May unsuspected bring your beauteous lady.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Lord what a broking advocate is this?
He was some Squiers scrivener, and hath scraped
Gentility out of attorney's fees ▪
His bastard actions prove him such a one,
For true worth scorns to turn chameleon.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Madam ▪ my uncle out of tender-love,
Better to shun all scandalous suspect,
That might attend on our unsuiting iodes
Will lodge you at his house, whither at times —

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Your grace may have access.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: 'Tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Is there a back way?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a private door,
A secret vault, and twenty odd tricks more.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A stove?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And arbours with sweet violet beds,
That have been pressed to death with maidenheads,
Where you may sport and breath, and take a rouse

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Pe , this lawyer keeps a bawdy house,
I shall be ready to deceive you all.
My lord, your law-plot's, most judicial.

div.p: But who comes here? some one of your cast clients.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: God's me, the countess.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mum, I cannot stay,
There's a cloud rising, drives my sun away.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Is this your wife?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis she that was.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: That was and is not? how comes that to pass?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I cannot tell, God and his conscience knows

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And the world sees colossus on my brows,
Hercules' pillars, here's none ultra writ.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Not in brass characters?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No, horns more fit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Hath not the law divorced and made a bar twixt our affections? wert not thou content to take a pension?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Which you still detain.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Good wit, law-tricks and firm, you may complain.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Complain I do, I kneel before the throne and sue for justice, but yet can purchase none.
Complain I do cousin.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: O, as you are a prince, and you a virgin.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I was one long since,
This is no place for passion, dry your eyes,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Grief nails me to the ground, I cannot rise,
I'll grow immodest, justice is exiled,
And so shall duty, patience turn wild,

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Come, leave the bedlam.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Do, for wit and law know she's a fool,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A couple quoth jackdaw.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: In passion lady.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Discontent or so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Be not, be counselled, do not let despair,
Like the rank cancer bred by sultry air.
Eat this young rose of beauty in the bud:
But in the April sun of youthful blood
Let the sweet blossom ripen, thrive and grow,
To those full joys which none but lovers know.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: The man talks idly, tell me I am fair,
Lovely and young.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You are, by love you are,
Not fair, you are: Leander's paramour:
Compared with you was a swarth blackamoor
Your hair is softer than the Colchean fleece,
Your well limned features, natures master piece
Your eyes too diamonds, set in purer mould
Than rocks of coral, or the Indian gold.
In thy smooth chin there is an ivory pit,
Where blushing Venus and young Cupid sit,
Feathering of golden shafts, the wounding heads,
Made of thy amber tresses finest threads.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: You will not buy me sure you praise me so.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Yet fair, I'll bid fair for you ere I go,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: He that bids fair for me deceives his eye.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: By heaven 'a doth not.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Wilful perjury, what means all this?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This my discourse intends,
Were husband's saints, some wives would have close friends.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Some bade perhaps, but —

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Husbands but for't, true, wilt? prithee wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Ud's hartlings do?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Do what?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Love-tricks quickly, wilt thou prithee.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: No, I prize my credit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Credit? life a man,
What talks of credit? art not known a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: You do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Damnation, what a gloss,
This gilded copper, diamond of glass,
What strange show it makes? I'll give you a color
Your face was ne'er worse painted, then I'll paint
Your wainscot credit, you are a private bit,
Kept for some great made dives. Red hot scandal
Suck the native colour of your souls
As it hath scorched thy credit, shriveld bawd,
Sponge, lemon-pill, and more irrelishable
Than o'erdried stockfish, fie.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Upon thy shame.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thy husband, oh thy husband's bow-legged fame
Death I shall hate thee.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: O for honour do.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Swear thou art my strumpet.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: I'll endure that to.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Shalt not deny't, heart, canst not.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Yes, I can.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Do't for thy life, thy soul, base courtesan.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Farewell, if friendship be at such a rate,
Before I'll purchased, I'll live still in hate.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Heart, a new fashion,
A lady poor, beautiful and chaste? clean
From the bias of custom: to be poor, painted,
And proud is as common in Genoa, as felt and feather
In the fortunate island: but chaste and poor,
As singular and rare, as conscience with the Anabaptist.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Come hither boy, didst never owe me service

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: Yes madam, more than ever I paid you honestly, and were 'a not my master.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Thy master, who?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Horatio, he that puts chastity to the quick, and honour to the stab, but I'll show him the nature of a right Frenchman, deny him homage, for swear allegiance, and come behind hand in cash keeping, and with his own purse maintain you against him.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Thy purpose briefly.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: In bald sentences, your noted wrongs are pitied.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Pitied, by whom?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: By me, lodgings prepared and diet, which I humbly tender your honour, as first payment of the ancient debt, my service owes you.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: But is the lodging private?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: At mine own mothers, and though I say't, she keeps an honest house, though my father be a citizen.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Of what profession?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Neither fool nor physician, but an ingenious pothecary.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: And what resort?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p:
Very civil and most quiet resort, patients, the
house is set round with patients twice or thrice a day, and because they'll be sure not to want drink, every one brings his own water in an urinal with him.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Doth a use physic too? that's beyond his warrant.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: O lord madam, better men than he strain courtesy with their warrants in this age, besides, you being musical, shall meet much content, for my mother lodges three or four knights and ladies' daughters that practise music and needlework, and will no doubt be exceeding proud of your company, wilt please you walk?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Thou art the star, by whom my fate is led, my shame's so public, I'd fain hide my head.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Current in law, and how encountered you. Wiu. I'll tell you my good lord (I thank my bringing up, I can talk, I use not to have my tongue to seek when it should pleasure any man, especially my good lord) I told her what a credit it was to have a man of great credit, and that which is more, a skilful lawyer that can stand out in her case at a dead life, and one that if need were, could make a crazy action sound, I put her in mind what it was to have such a one to her sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou speakst but right, for so I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: You are, I urged it, and she confessed to me that the very first night she saw you she dreamt on you, and wished you in her bed, and her bed in the midst of the river.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How, ith' the river?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes for sooth,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the middle of the tide.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Yes in her dream.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Good,
But she doth love me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Believe it my lord she doth, marry you must think I drew her and drew her, and wrought her and wrought her, till I made her as pliant and, tractable table as wax, marry with all, she is as constant as Lucretia, and will not for a thousand pounds, till she hath the law of her side.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: I sound her meaning, first I'll gull my nephew.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Her intent right, she intends to make a gull of the prince, and an absolute goose of you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Still good in law, I'll fetch him o'er of all,
Get all, purse all, and be possessed of all,
And then conclude the match, marry at least,
When can you tell? I'll use her as a hand
To pick the prince's coffers, and for reward
To prison, marry her, for tricks can do't, (Actions.
The world's squint-eyed, and dares not pry into our
Here lies her walk (My lute win) she shall see,
Youth's leaden footed in respect of me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Win, prithee give the fiddler a testar and fend him packing, what a scraping the tongue keeps? does 'a think the count keeps a tavern or a bawdy-house? my good lord! beseech your honour pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No harm sweet love, how dost thou like this caper?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Passing well my lord, will you never leave these coltish tricks? but to the matter: I sent you my resolution by your maid, have you received it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I have, and it holds currant,
Then tender me possession.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Of thy chaste love.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Not too much haste for that, you have a wife.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I had one.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And still have.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Thy love shall quickly wed her to her grave, I ne'er did love her.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: When she was a maid
You swore you did, how soon poor youth's betrayed
To helpless ruin ▪ do you love me?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I'faith.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For how long?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Till death.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: O deadly lie.
I'll tell you just how long, love's bred i'th blood,
Prospers as long as beauties in the bud.
When beauty withers, lustful love grows cold,
And ere it be half ripe, 'tis rotten old.
If you have me, you must not put on yellows,
I'll have my self, my servant and my fellows.
My love, my liking, and a second me,
I love to relish sweet variety:
Your old wife moved you, I shall vex you more.
Take coach with gallants even a sore your door.
Take rings, give bracelets woven of my hair,
Which to spite you, my servant's arm shall wear.
I'll in your presence sit upon his knee,
Exchanging kisses if you speak to me.
I'll pont in scorn, cry mew, and look aside,
At which, if you but frown, I'll roundly chide,
I am not as I seem, dissembling wit
Is my best means.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Square to my humour fit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I was a beggar born.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And so was I.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.l: Traded in lust and gainful brothelry.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The fitter for my turn, I was a man
Born to no hopes, but a few shreds of wit
a grammar scholar, than a scrivener.
Dealing for private use twixt man and man,
And by close broke age set them at debate:
Incensed them unto law, which to maintain,
I lent them money upon lands and plate,
After the rate of sevenscore in the hundred.
Then did I learn to counterfeit men's hands,
Noblemen's arms, interline evidences,
Make false conveyances, yet with a trick,
Close and cocksure, I coney-catched the world.
Having scraped pretty wealth, I fell in league
With my first wife, and (Though I say't myself)
She had good doings, her back comings in
And private goings out, raised me aloft:
I followed cases of the law abroad,
And she was merry with her friends at home.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did you ne'er take her kissing?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Twenty times.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Were you not jealous?

sp.speaker: Lur
sp.l: Never nothing less.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Yet saw her kiss with strangers.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Kiss and play.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And were you a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Cuckold by this light.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What? A wittal.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And a wittal too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And knew't?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And knew't.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And suffered it.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I did.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: It went attired in gold, a golden crest,
Is a brave fashion, and accounted best.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.l: Madam, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The prince.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The prince.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And Julio.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Which way?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: From thence.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: That way the vault, from thence the private door, as I stood sentinel at the further end of the vault, they being unacquainted with the turnings, came groping and feeling, as commonly men will do especially in a strange place, and as I am true sinner, had I not spied the diamond on his finger (Twin, to this a my conscience) they had been upon me in the dark ere I had been aware of them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: The prince.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: And Julio.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Quick away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What plot?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Behind the arras? scaped behind the arras.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Behind the arras.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Close, cock, sure, be wise,
They only thrive that best can temporize.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A rare vault by this light, and never devised without the advice of a grand jury of bawds, a word with your lips Tris.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: As god mend me prince you smell bawdy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Since I came into thy company win. And how is't Tris? fore-god a pretty lodging.

sp.speaker: Inl.
sp.l: And very fair hangings.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Passing good workmanship, what story is this Tris?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Why my lord? the poetical fiction of Venus kissing Adonis in the violet bed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Fore-god 'tis true, and mark where the cuckoldly knave Vulcan stands sneaking behind the
brake bush to watch a ▪ m.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: A pretty conceit Julio, dost see Vulcan with the horning parenthesis in his forehead! I hit indirectly upon the left pap at three passes for a hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Not for a hundred.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is't a match?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis done, where will you take your stand?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here, anywhere , heart has the arras an ague, it trembles so?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No, Vulcan's fearful.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: And with a fear it comes, have at the cuckold.

sp.speaker: Lnr.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Hark, the arras is in labour.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Mass I heard something groan.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: I'll be the midwife and help to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Sweet prince.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Hark wench, I smell boar's grease.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Will you but hear me?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Now excuse what trick? She whispers to him.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How? but a picture? I'll try that presently,
If you love me, disfigure it not, I esteem it only for
The lively workmanship.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then let me have a sight on't.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Upon condition you'll neither deface it with weapon, nor soil it with your breath —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: On my virginities maidenhead we will not discover Lurdo behind the arras.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Heart a the devil, your uncle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O forbear, fore God passing good workman indeed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Mark but the glance of his eye.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The hanging of his neither lip.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The blush of his cheek.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: The curl of his hair.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The pit of a chin.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What a smooth hand 'a hath?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Long fingers like a lady.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Not so much but a seal ring.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Arms and all, viz a tame gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: And the fool swallows it rarely, and you mark him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Is the numb ass insensible of scoffs?
I'll touch him nearer, yet mine eye deceives me,
And this be not count Lurdo's counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You may soon know that my lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If it be his, 'a hath the gout in his left foot,

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: The very same, his shoe is cut and all, farewell Tris, and yet I'll startle him a little better afore we leave him, fore-god 'tis so like him, I doubt, whether it be the shadow or his substance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A block.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: A shadow.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A mere senseless stone.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then 'tis a counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: An absolute counterfeit, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Marry many counterfeits walk in the likeness of good money, and so may this do, which to prevent I'll nail him to a post, for fear a pass currant on your lips in my absence, and so deceive me?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I'll swear 'a shall not, gentle prince be short,
Length kills the heart of the most feeling sport.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Well maiden, I am content, this jest shall reprieve your head for this once, but beware the next encounter, come Ariadne's clew, will you unwind, and light us through this vault of darkness, and there's your naulum.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p:
Thank you my lord, and your business stand this way at midnight, I'll let you in by this token, and take this from me, when you come again, bring the
lady a diamond, or some pretty and foolish stone, for I can tell you these same paltry stones are in high request amongst ladies, especially such old mousers as I have been in my time, and as I say when you come, be not ashamed to knock, and if I come not knock lustily, and again, and never give over knocking till you hear my hem, did you never know wins hem?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why hast thou a private hem?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Have I? I'faith sir I, few gallants ith' town that are of any standing at all, but are acquainted with my hem, but come close my lord, close, and be sure the next time you come you do not forget to knock lustily,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My love, my life, o thou art made
Out of the soul of wit, and thy conceits,
Of the best fashion.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Did you taste the jest?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: Divinely, o divinely, tart and quick,
Pleasing, yet not tedious I was wrapped

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: In a knave's skin.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My senses were entranced.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Into a fool's paradise.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: O my sweet phoenix, out of thy ashes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Is your love so hot, you mean to burn me ▪

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: O fit honeyed me,
And then their numbness, didst thou never read
Of any lawyer came to be Duke?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Never, but I have heard of a cuckold that was an usurper.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Why such a one would I be.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What, a cuckold?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes, and an usurper too.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: So you are for you lawyers usurp more crowns than half a country.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ulysses, Tully, lawyers, but no Dukes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Menelaus and Vulcan were cuckolds but no lawyers.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: For-me 'tis true, but now I do remember naught to that purpose:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The most lustful goats
Wear guilded horns, and go in velvet coats.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What news win?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Faith ordinary household news, yonder's a well-faced gentleman craves 'a may change a word with you.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Horatio.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Leave us to confer.
A trusty friends, the soul's high treasurer.

div.p: In dumps Horatio? what, my second self clouded with passion?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: O my honoured lord, our souls and our affections are made all of one fashion now the slightest wrong that scars the reputation of my friend, stabs daggers to my heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know it true, and I can prove't,
Our loves are twins,
But to the wrong, dares any idle tongue
Bark at our greatness?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Their names?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My wife? the manner?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Amongst her lustful mates,
She shames not to give out, that by your greatness,
Knowledge, credit, and friends in highest place,
You have divorced her without due desert.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: We must demur of this, I'll have a trick
by way of habeas corpus to remove
This talking gossip, come Horatio,
Some project, how? what course for her remove:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I cannot counsel, but fore-god my lord,
My lodgings mightily annoyed with rats,
That eat my papers and deface my books
How should I rid them.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Easily, poison them,
And well remembered, this she rat my wife,
That eats and tears the leaves of my repute,
Shall taste like speeding physic in thine ear,
Canst temper poison?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And kill a rat.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That she shall never swell on't.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Mum for that,
This she rat is a devil.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A limb of Sathan.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Envy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Destruction.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Malice.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ratsbane do't?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Ere my disgrace get age, rare tricks and I will fool the world, wilt, do't?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The rate shall die.

div.stage: Enter countess, three or four young gentlewomen, sowing by an hourglass.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Quick pretty damsels, that your task were done the forenoon's eldest minutes almost run.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: Then the glass runs to fast.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: I think not so,
Hadst thou my cares, thou'dst think it ran too slow.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: I have my task forsooth.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: So have not I.
Yet with these sands my sorrows run away
I turn them with the glass, the glass is run,
Yet my huge mass of cares is scarce begun,
Here's a fault, little one what work make you.

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: True stitch forsooth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Then see you work it true.

sp.speaker: 3 gent.
sp.l: Pray madam teach me to take out this knot of heart's ease.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Heart's ease, I have almost forgotten,
I could have wrought it well when I was young:
But in good sadness, I have had none long.
What's that?

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: A branch of rue.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: A common weed, of all herbs else I work that well indeed, how chance your flower is behind the glass?

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Indeed I'll get it up:

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Indeed alas.
I cannot chide with her, yet tyrant care,
At my entreat will not one sight forbear:

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Why sigh you madam?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: O I grieve to see,
Youth run to cath at their own misery.
You are like April or rose buds in may,
You never wither, till the wedding day,
Even so did I, so pretty souls will you,
Youth wears mild hearts ease, marriage bitter rue.

sp.speaker: 2 Gen.
sp.l: Be not so sad, good madam, do b ut smile,
We'll have a song sad sorrow to beguile.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Save you fair ladies, madam, my business leads me to you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: If in your ancient suit,
My cares are deafened and my utterance mute.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Your ear, be wood, what should beget this coins
were I a stranger, or some city gull
I would commend thee, but I know the world.
Lodging is costly, maintenance asks charge:
Thou art divorced and haste no other help,
But thy bare comings in: accept my love,
I will allow thee twenty pound a quarter.
To buy thee pins.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Leave this modest suit.
Or by my honour —

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, these words of course
My fame, mine honour, and my dear respect:
Are but like ignes fatui to delude,
Green and unseasoned wits, pry thee be kind,
A guilded slip carries as fair a show,
As perfect gold, guilt honour may do so

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: But put your slip to trial, the slight gold,
Is soon rubbed of:

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come, thy distinctions sold
Let not thy April beauty like a rose,
Fade in the bud, and ripened pleasures lose,
My sword thy honour: thy estate my purse,
Shall man and strengthen,

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I detest that course.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your husband hath a sweet heart:

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: For his ill.
Shall I turn traitor and mine own fame kill?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: 'Tis ▪ dead already, every idle tongue, stabs it to death.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I have the greater wrong.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thou wrongest thyself and spurnest thy proper good
Am I not youthful see my wanton blood
Danceth within my veins, and blushing, courts
Thy generous beauty to more amorous sports,
You shall not choose.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Hands of.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I love the e dear.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I hate thee deadly.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dost thou?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Shall I swear?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: No, I'll believe thee phoenix of thy sex,
I glory in thy virtues, and reveal,
What by my oath I promised to conceal.
Your jealous husband urged me to this try all,
Pawning his oath upon your strict deny all,
All bastard jealousy should be exiled,
And ancient love entirely reconciled.
I touched your heart, and now I find it true,
I'll give you notice, I'll impoison you.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Thou speak'st all comfort.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I was made of hope. and rich performance waits upon my words.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.p: Father of my fair fortunes, whose rich love begets this reuniting covenant,
sp.l: When comes this long expected sealing day?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tomorrow, the hour eight.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Certain?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As life.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Then follow me to feast,
Thy news Horatio is the welcomest guest.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Swell heart, hold bosom, yield not to relent,
And yet her beauty, colourable trash,
Her virtues, vengeance hypocritical,
I love her, fury, poison, Hidra's gall,
Impatience man me, black damnation
Usher my practice, poison play thy part,
And do my latest greetings to her heart.
We all must down, yet here the difference lies.
Many for sins, she for her virtue dies.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Polymetes Julio, Horatio, Emilia and pages

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: T Tristella.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Good wine needs no bush, nor a good face
painging thou art favour of thyself, and what thou cost is not under a colour.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I know no other painter but one, and her name is modesty, and she sometimes throws a blush into my face to make my pale cheeks red, but else you shall never take me for an alderman's post.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Why an alderman's poet?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Mark but where great posts are newly painted, you shall see much egress and regress in and out, and where you see a face newly ochered, 'tis a sign there's great traffic, and much stirring to and fro.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come sit, sit, nay nearer, nearer, nearer yet.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then I shall sit upon your skirts.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Julio and Horatio, what shall's have to supper?
I am now in the spending vain.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then God for me ▪ what make I so near?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Good action, you shall not remove, I learned that phrase of mine uncle, boy, know what Adam hath bespoken for our palates.
sp.l: Where there a banquet to be had,
More rate and dear, then that Vitellius made:
It should be served in, but Horatio,
What shall we eat that's costly, and that's rare?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: A roated phoenix were excellent good for that lady.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And why for that lady.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Fare etched and dear bought, is good for you know who

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: For ladies.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I for ladies.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Then the most cheap stuff, and next to hand is good for you know who.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: For knaves.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I for knaves.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Adam what have you ready.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Sir you may have a calf's head.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Here's a gentleman hath one in his hat already, no more. Calf's head I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Hast any pheasants or partridges?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: No, but if your lordship will have a dish of woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: No for godsake, they are the stalest meat with me of any, for I never sit to meat with these gallants, but there's woodcocks clean through the table.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Then unless you will have a Dotrell or a gull.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: A gull? why which of these gent. wilt thou serve in? do you not hear how Adam flouts you?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: I mean a seagull baked.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: I in any case let's have that, I have fed my wit on many a land-gull, once let me banquet myself of a seagull, some sea captain, I lay my life that has a desire to sup with me, but such as thou hast, I prithee be brief

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Lay the table in the withdrawing room.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: I will sir, your honour can have no larks I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Two citizens sons and a poet bought up all ith' town, flung away the bodies only to have a pie made of the brains.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.p: A sign either they lacked brains, or else they did it because they would bear a brain.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: T was told me that the young lord Polymetes was entered here.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: He that so told thee fellow told thee true.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I cry your lordship mercy, let this letter
Supply th'unwilling office of my tongue,
And be the sad reporter of my news.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.l: What ominous news can Polimetes daunt?
Have we not hyren here?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ovid not all thy metam metamorphosis
Can show such transformation, o my God!
It is not possible, (Is this my son?)
'A has mistaken himself, my life 'a has,
For the seven liberal sciences; 'a reads,
The seven black deadly fins.
Must you needs son turn over these linen leaves
Having such store of paper? this is miraculous.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: News, news my hearts will make your jocund souls dance in your bosoms, now which joyful tongue amongst you all cries first god save the Duke? God save Duke Polymetes.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The news is not so happy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Tush look here.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My lord I'm sorry for your heaviness .

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Thou shouldst have said so to a porter that's heavy loaden.
But come, sit, sit in council, let's devise
How to spend all this countless mass of wealth,
My father hath bequeathed me at his death,
Quite from the popular and vulgar garb,
We will be ode in all things, and retain
No common humour in our large expense.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: An honourable mind, and were your father
Alive to note these hopeful parts in you,
How would it move him and surprise his heart?
But now my lord: my message being done,
I must return I'm glad I have found your son.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: For thy good news take that along with thee,
Look here Tris, would not these
Make notable statesmen? methinks state steals upon me.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And I have known some steal state.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Then they came never truely by it as I do, but pergite porro, methinks I could make an indifferent careless Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: And I could make a notable courtier, methinks I am begging already.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O mine uncle would make an excellent court spaniel, he would sent out offices and concealed lands, a hundred mile of, and a were my cashier but twenty years, I durst change livings with him.

sp.speaker: Emi.
sp.l: But what employment for Horatio?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O, he would make a good grumbling surly politician, thou shalt be my politician.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I shall never be loved.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not loved, your reason?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I hate the base and rascal multitude,
I cannot nod, ride barehead through the streets,
Nor wreathe my body like a cable hatband
To every pedlar and mechanic townsman,
I hate the poor, am envious at the rich,
Love none.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Yes, women.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Faith after a sort, I love a good smooth face ▪

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Then you love mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And forty more.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I muse you do not marry.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I would tonight , upon condition
That I might bury her tomorrow, God boy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Fill him some wine.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: I cannot drink, god boy.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: It is not poisoned.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hum, I cannot tell,
The countess drunk and died.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p:
Still in the bags of melancholy, pax on't, 'tis staler
than tobacco, not so much but the singing cobbler is grown melancholy, and corrects shoes in humour, fie on't, come sit, we must talk about many matters, Rivo, I'll be singular, my royal expense shall run such a circular course that the rascal spawn of imitators shall split their wooden brains, and sink their wealth in the gulf of prodigality, and yet like a bad archers shaft, fall sixscore short of their aim, my expense shall be royal and peculiar.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I'll fashion you a course.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Divinely, come.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Divinely indeed, serve God, live honestly ▪ relish not atheism.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That's clean out of the fashion indeed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Then good.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Because out of the fashion, set down that Adam

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: 'Tis done ▪

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I have't my lord, I have't i'faith.

sp.speaker: Po
sp.l: Nay quickly, how?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We'll keep no pages.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Excellent, that's clean out of the fashion for pages, that's good, that stands, down with it Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: We'll use no great horses.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How shall we ride then?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: On mules and she asses.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Down with that Adam.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But, for my train, for a page with pages,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Maintain a hundred gallants at your heels,
Live in the country, entertain again
Into the court, long-banished hospitality,
sp.p: Who since the first great hose with codpieces grew out of fashion ne'er durst show his head.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p:
Another, set it down, I'll spend after forty pound a day, I'll see which of my chevril brained imitators dares follow my fashion: 'sblood I cannot drink tobacco
two days, but the third the church wardens and sidemen are at it in the alehouse in sermon time, I cannot wear a suit half a day but the tailor's journeyman creeps into't: I cannot keep a block private, but every citizen's son thrusts his head into it: I cannot keep a wench but every Grand-juror's son in the country imitates me, I care not if I make it petty treason for any man to kiss under ten pound a kiss.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: O my lord, 'twill never pass ith' the lower-house, they will not lose their liberty of kissing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then keep a leash of wenches.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: As common as cracking of nuts, not a servingman, but doth as much.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Fore-god I have't, peculiar I have't.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: What is't Julio?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Your honour shall keep no wenches at all.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: No wenches? what shall become of me then?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I must be round with you Tris, you must pack, many women they say are common, and I'll entertain nothing that savours of community, I will not divulge.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Nay, but hark you my lord, though you maintain me, you do not lie with me, and I think that's the newer fashion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Fore-god the newest of all, for there's not a gallant maintains his wench but 'a will lie with her, down with that Adam.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: My lord my lord, the Duke your father with a great train is coming.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: From heaven or hell.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: That's more than I know, but by the faith of a page, or the word of a gent. which you will, he is arrived and in great state entered the city.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Zounds where's the slave that brought the false report of his death?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: But art sure 'tis my father?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Or else your mother did you the more wrong, shift for yourselves, for he is come.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My father alive and come home, heart a me what shift? come home and find the court turned alehouse dicing-house, dancing school, I am undone horse and foot.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Some rosa-solis or aqua mirabilis ho, for our general coward's in a swoon.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: I know you are a hot shot in a featherbed Tris, but that will vot serve turn now, therefore fall off, the enemy is too strong, deed Tris, every lamb to his fold, and coney to her borough, for the old fox is abroad no, wilt not be? why then God a mercy's brain.
Cedant arma togae, my gown and books boy, some sudden device to keep him back half an hour, and win my good opinion for ever.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: And I do not, let me die of the bastinado .

div.stage: Enter Duke Ferneze, Angelo, and other nobles attendants.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lords, make a stand, I wonder that our son glads not our wished arrival with his presence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No doubt my lord, his honourable care,
Is not acquainted with your sudden landing.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: We take it so, and whilst ourself in person
Inquire the cause, attend us in the hall,
Little thinks he his father is so near,
But unexpected, I'll go startle him,
And put his wit unto the present try all.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Where's the prince?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: My most honoured lord?
In private conference with an English post.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: An English post?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: An English post my lord: the effect of his letters I know, not but I heard him begin a most strange discourse.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Of what I prithee?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Please your honour take a turn or two, I shall relate (Quickly my lord) he reports there fell such an inundation of waters in the month of July, about the third of dog-days, that the oars and scullers that use to work in the Thames, rowed over houses and landed their fairs in the middle I'll of Paul's.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Very easily possible ('sfoot quickly) and more the fishermen that rid between Dover and Calis, took red spurlin, and she mackerel in the midst of the exchange, which made mutton so cheap and stale, that it is thought the better half of the townsmen will run horn mad about it.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It cannot be.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not be? why look you sir,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p:
But hear the conclusion, just on saint Luke's day coming shall be a twelvemonth, Westminster and Winchester, drinking a quart of wine together on salisbury-plain fell into hard words and strange terms, there was thou knave and I knave, and such foul words, as if tow young barristers had been breathing their wits for a wager, ('sfoot make an end) now it was thought Westminster stood most upon his terms, yet in the end Winchester got one of his best terms
from him spite on his teeth, which so vexed Westminster, that it grew to a deadly feud, which was so hotly pursued that the taking up of the matter cost many broken heads.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.p: So sir, ('sfoot not done yet?) and had not Charing-cross a tall bow legged gent: taken up the matter, 'tis thought Westminster stones would have been too hot for some of them: and in parting the fray, Charing-cross got such a box o'the ear, that he will carry it to his deathsday, some say a got a wry neck by parting the fray, marry Winchester says flatly, a got a crick in his neck, with looking westward for termers.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou shouldst have told me.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Of the English post ▪ why look you my lord, the post coming in post-haste to show his duty to the prince, stumbled at a post that lay in his way and broke his sinister shank, and so I break of my discourse and bid your honour welcome home.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What a strange tale is here? of floods and hills of Charing-cross, terms ▪ and I know not what? and when I looked for the conclusion.
sp.l: A breaks of all and leaves me in a cloud.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: There is some trick in't, honoured ▪ Julio?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Health to my sovereign.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How fares our son?
Have your inducements drawn him from his humour?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Faith my lord I have done a child's part, and almost spent a child's part, to draw him to society, but 'tis labour lost.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What is his business with the English post?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p:
The English post my lord? your grace is
merry.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: His boy informed me a held conference,
Bout serious matters with an English post.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Alas my lord, the boy is lunatic.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How lunatic? and afore god methought
'A told a mad discourse, but th' occasion.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: I tell you my lord, coming a abruptly as your honour or any else may do to the prince's chamber, about some ordinary service, a found him in his study, and a company of bottle-nosed devils dancing the Irish hay about him, which on the sudden so startled the poor boy, as a clean lost his wits, and ever since talks thus idle, as your excellence hath heard him

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: But tell me doth my son converse with devils?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: As familiarly as you and I, they are his only company keepers, when a hath been dulled at his study, I have known a devil and he play at tick-tack for Phillip's, by the whole day together.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: 'Tis passing strange, but may we without danger go near his study?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: At your honour's pleasure,

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: See where 'a sits, be patient and observe.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Prevented still? now by Medusa's snakes,
And black Erinys ever burning lamp,
If all the skill in pyromantic rules,
Deep aeromancy, or the precious soul,
Of Germanic spells and characters
Graven in the surface of our mother earth,
can work this strange achievement,

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: How his brain sweats in pursuit of learning

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O attend.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: The first house is vulgarised, the horoscope or angle of the orient, and his ascendant betokeneth beginning of life, merchandise, marriage and —

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Let's break him off.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: The second and third house, the third house is cadent from the angle of the orient, and ascendant to the angle septentional, signifying father's sisters and daughters absent and lost, daughters and fathers lost: here then I find my demand, the maid lost my sister, thus than I proportion my figure, there I place my witnesses, and here my judge, and thus proceed to the invocation.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Renowned prince, prince Polymetes, zounds prince.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Discourteous Julio, give my study leave.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Heart not a jot, the Duke your father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I'll make my father joyful by my toil,
Had not thy folly interiupted me,
My hopes ere this had met their period.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your princely father.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: O torment me not with his remembrance.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Sblood he's safe returned.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: O would a were, then should not Genoa's crown,
For want of strong supportance be pressed down.
I 〈…〉 not enough, that like a harmless prince
Spending my hours in contemplation,
I let you hold the reins of government.
Unfit for me, my father hath a deep
And searching judgement that can brush and sweep
such idle brained and antique parasites,
Forth of his presence, pray your absence,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I can but smile to sue how Protheus like,
They turn the shape of their discourse and project,
Thinking to lead me in an idle maze,
After their folly, well, I'll temporize,
And note the issue, come my lords let's in,
His humour's grounded, and like subtle fire:
The more suppressed, it mounts so much the hire.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Why so, this jest came smoothly of and was not soiled in the working

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: That boy is worth his weight in pearl, didst mark what a tale of a cock and a bull, he told my father whilst I made thee and the rest away, by a bill of conveyance at his back?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: And I did simple knights service in persuading the Duke the boy was lunatic.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: 'Twas admirable, doth not this jest deserve to be chronicled?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: No by my troth, yet I must needs say, some as bad have been, for howsoever our practice pass currant with your father for the present, our villainies must needs break ▪ forth, they are so notorious and public.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: No matter let ▪ am, have not we brains? brains and they be well minced are sauce for any meat, let mine uncle turn turxe and break forth, let the whole town turn cuckold and blow their horns in our disgrace, I have brains, let the sun and the seven stars be opposed, I have brains for that too my present wit shall give ▪ am all the lie in their throats, and may maintain it at pocket, dagger, and pistol when I have done.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A mourner boy? what solemn funeral,
Hath hung that sable livery on thy back?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Her death my lord that hath cut out the like,
For both your honours, the countess is deceased.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then will my uncle be a heavy mourner.
But how the manner of her death?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I'll tell your honour that hereafter and give you the ground of an admirable jest .

sp.speaker: Pol.
