sp.p: And we play not true moles and work it out of the ground, let me die of the green-sickness.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The ground then comes?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: No I'll tell you that in private, the life of a jest thrives in the first revealing, it concerns the manner of your aunt's death and a law-trick of your uncle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Come to the slemn rites, and weep at least those being ended we'll receive y our jest. Exeunt.solemn music to a funeral song the hearse borne over the stage, Duke Lurdo, Polymetes, Angelo, Julio, Horatio and mourners etc.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: What is a man? heart a the devil mere fools,
His rich invention, Machiavellian plots:
Idle illusive antic fantasies.
Apelles' grapes, I had as full a brain,
Fertile invention and as forward hopes,
As man could father, or his wit bring forth:
Yet in a minute in bubbles age,
The venomed fury of a bitter spleen,
Confounded all, forgetful that I was,
Women are moulded out of bashfulness:
And must be drawn to kindness by degrees.
All this I knew.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Neither the law nor I,
know any reason why Horatio.
But mum, law-tricks as closely as I can,
Mine ear shall drink his meditation.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Had she survived time —

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Might have found us out,
Good, firm in law, I am a fool to doubt,
His constant secrecy.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But now she's dead.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: The deepest wit could not have bettered,
Our smooth conveyance, but upright and straight,
Unknown, unseen, I'll work upon conceit.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Had she been living, golden promises,
The smoothe attorneys to a lover's tongue
Might have in time solicited my suit,
Gifts might have pleaded, mournful elegies,
Told her my passions, had she been composed
Of steel or flint, nay, made of women's hearts,
The most obdurate mettle, time and art,
But she is dead, o hell! and in her tomb.
My hopes are buried.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My conceited brain,
Hath an odd crotchet called me back again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: To all these bad misfortunes should the corn use any tricks?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Ha? 'a talks of tricks,
Of count and tricks, for tricks and count are twins.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yet I regard not.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I am right and straight.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Say a complain?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Suppose he tell the Duke he gave the poison.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He contrived her death and cannot wrong me,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Fie, I fear him not,
He doth but father, what my brain begotten.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: This comfort yet which many want I have,
To follow my fair fortunes to the grave.

div.head: Actʋs qʋintʋs
div.stage: Enter horatios page with a thief's lauthorne.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: O, shall I venture? ha, shall I enter?
Shield me Apollo, the ground is so hollow
That every step I tread upon it,
Methinks it sings a dead man's sonnet.
Fates, o fates be honest drabs,
Fear gives me ten thousand stabs,
I dare not further 'tis wilful murder,
Thus late to tread the cloister vaults.
For though I'm small, I have great men's faults,
Then gentle fates, take some remorse,
I watch an honest, kind, quick course.
Grant that no hobgoblins fright me,
No hungry devils rise up and bite me:
No urchin, elves, or drunkards ghosts,
Shove me against walls or posts,
Oh grant I may no black thing touch,
Though many men love to meet such.
But here's the tomb, my hopes sufficing,
I watch a dainty ducks uprising,
Her cheeks now are chilly, as is the pale lily, (Roses)
But when her eye uncloses, they'll look like two fair
A light my master? or some spright,
Yet what need devils have candlelight,
'Tis he, all hid, I'll not be seen,
For once this tomb shall be my screen.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I cannot rest, my guilt keeps ope mine eyes.
My passion rips my bosom, and my blood
Is turned to poisoned water, and so swells,
That my vexed soul, endures a thousand hells.
If I chance slumber, than I dream of serpents,
toads, altogether, and such venomous evils,
As hale me from my sleep like forked devils,
Midnight, thou Aethiop, empress of black souls,
Thou general bawd to the whole word, I salute thee,
Wishing thy poison dropped upon my brain,
For my so rude, so rash, so heedless murder,
In the ambition and the height of lust,
Not giving my blood liberty to cool.
To poison such a beauty, oh black fate!
Thus many killed, too soon repent too late.
Soft, stay, this same's the chilly monument,
That hugs her body in his marble arms.
Thou gentle soul of my deceased love?
O, wert but possible to enjoy thy voice,
Thy sweet harmonious voice, I should be blessed,
But e'en to dally with thy syllables,
Oh tomb.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No tomb but cistern filled with tears.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: O heart!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No heart, but sink of grief and fears.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Countess, soul shadow, shadow speak again ▪

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Speak again.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: What should I speak, my hate, or thy huge wrongs?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Huge wrongs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Huge wrongs indeed, but charitable soul,
What ransom shall I pay thee for thy life?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Thy life.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: My life?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: 〈…〉 life.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Discourteous air,
My blood is frozen with despair.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Despair.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Pardon forgive me, shall I go?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But shall your hate pursue me, I or no?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Adieu my grief and I'll go sleep.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Pray God my tongue can my heart's counsel keep

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Ha? are you vanished? let me see, 'a may be fallen asleep against some pillar, for I'll be sworn a talked very idly, about decessit evasit erupit, I would fain know that wag that can put me down for a woman's ghost extempore, especially if it were to be performed under a tomb cloth, but here lay the desperate venture, had she chanced to have risen, and spoke before her cue, as about this time she must 'tice, or my sleepy drink plays, the drowsy companion with her.
Heart a me, my master again, what cross points are these? I see I must betake me to my late refuge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It was no ghost, subtle opinion,
Working in man's decayed faculties,
Cuts out and shapes illusive fantasies,
And our weak apprehensions like wax,
Receive thee from, and presently convey
Unto our dull imagination.
And hereupon we ground a thousand lies,
As that we see devils rattling their chains,
Ghosts of dead men, variety of spirits,
When our own guilty conscience is the hell.
And our black thoughts, the caverns where they dwell:
Yet sure this was her shadow, for I hear
Her last words sound still dancing in mine ear.
Then gentle soul ▪ if thou beest yet unthroned,
Answer one question and no more.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No more?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: May my hearts true repentance satisfy,
My willful ▪ murder, your reply.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Thanks, thousand thanks, and so farewell.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: The bane of murder is despair and hell.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Was ever poor little knave put to his last trumps as I am? what shall I do now ▪ my heart goes pit a pat in my belly like a pair of washing beetles, should a return again now, as my hand to a lobster-pie 'a will, all the fat were in the fire, but hark 'tis one o'clock , and just about this minute she should play the wagtail and stir.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What trance was this? where am I?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: O she speaks, fates and be good girls keep my master away, and let his man have a little sport with his mistress.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What place is this? am I in heaven or no.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What voice is that? is this place earth?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Earth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Earth? how came I hither? do I live again?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Live again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What voice is that? A woman or some youth?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Youth.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: My fears will murder me, my powers are frighted.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Alas poor stirring ghost art over sprighted.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tell me.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: All and more anon.
The sleepy drink hath played the honest man,

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: What sleepy drink? how came I in this tomb?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.l: I'll tell you that in a more private room,
Away I'll tell you a strange wonder,
Then winter lightning, or Christmas thunder,
Then to my father's trip and go,
Nimble prevention on't runs woe.

div.stage: Enter Ferneze the Duke, count, Lurdo, Angelo, Horatio and Adam with others attendant.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No more of mourning brother, we have laid
Our timeless sorrows in a quiet grave,
When men inter their comfort let them weep:
Not when their crying charm is laid to sleep.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Great Duke mine eyes are not thus great with tears,
For our grief's funeral, but that her shame,
And future scandal will out live her name,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Come let mirth kill it, and to your discourse,
Is our son grown unto that height of riot
Your speeches intimate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I know the law, if I have wronged the prince,
I stand in compass of a praemunire,
And he by written of ad quod dampnum may,
Sue his recovery, I know the law.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Nay his own letter partly grants as much,
But note his subtle reason, here a writ's,
That of set purpose a laid by himself,
And played the part of a wild prodigal,
Only to put your love unto the test,
On which advantage to increase his wealth,
You did endear him to society,
Of careless wantons and light courtesans,
Made secret vaults and cellars under ground.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Non tenet in bocardo I demur,
Do but send out your iterum summoneas,
Or capias ut legatum to attach,
And bring him viva voce tongue to tongue,
And vi et armis I'll revenge this wrong.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Leave that to trial, here a further writte●,
That by his skill and practice in black art,
He hath found out and by much toil redeemed,
My daughter from the Turkish servitude.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Redeemed your daughter ▪ an apparent error,
Which you by way of melius inquirendum .
May soon discuse, he ran some home your daughter
As sure as I made cellars under ground,
Or played his pandar.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How so ere it prove,
I mean to try the utmost of his wit,
To see how quaintly he can bear himself:
But who comes here.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.p: Marry my good lord, this is the green burr, that stuck so close to the young prince's sleeve, the shoemakers cutting knife, that fitted his boots to the prodigals last.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: If I be compos mentis, this is she,
Must play your daughter's part, my lord be ware,
Work close cock sure, I see the gin the snare.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Most reverend father.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Father? now it fits,
Beware an old fox, Duke I have brains I have wits.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Immodest impudent and shameless girl,
Is't not enough thou hast misled my son,
And wrong his reputation?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: How wronged him father? I must needs say I have played will with the wisp with my brother and have led him up and down the maze of good fellowship, till I have made his wit and his wealth both turn sick but for any other wrong, I appeal to himself, my uncle honest Julio, where is 'a? and all the rest of this good audience, therefore pray good father.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Out of my sight, thou art no child of mine,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p:
You're the more beholding to some of your neighbours, tut man look on me well, here's your now ne nose, and thick kissing lip up and down, and my
mother were living, she would never buss you more, till you confessed I were your daughter.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What an audacious naughty pack is this?
Have her before a justice, Adam.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Do, with all my heart good father, send me to a justice, for a pretty woman with a smooth tongue and an angel's voice, can do much with justice in this golden age, but thus much afore I go, if justice will not provide me a better father, I'll have you, or I'll give the beadle of the ward a fee to cry, a new father a new, as they do oysters at Callais.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Brother ere you acquainted with this woman?

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: I must needs say that at my nephew's suit,
I gave her a month's lodging and her diet.
But nada veritate in bare truth,
Et bona side without circumstance,
Splendente sole the bright sun never saw,
A wench more capable of wit and law,
And howsoe'er she is with beauty graced,
I dare engage mine honour she is chaste,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I give your words good credit, yet 'tis rare,
To find a woman wanton, chaste and fair,
But now unto my son, whose powerful art,
Strives to ungive his sister's servitude.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Thanks he eat, thou hast ensphered my hope
In a gold circle, o were my father here,
This fight would of his age bate twenty year.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What sight my son.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Lend me your watery eye,
That swims in passion for my sister's loss,
And in this book prospective, let it read,
A pleasing lecture.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I conceive two shapes.
A civil merchant and a bewteous maid.
Their pace is speedy and my slower eye,
cannot keep way with their celerity.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: That maid's my sister, whom on magic's wing,
To this fair presence, my rich art shall bring,
Prepare to meet them, for this minute's age,
Sends with my charm their airy pilgrimage.

div.stage: Enter Julio like a merchant, and Joculo like a lady.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Where are are we now? how strangely were we born
Upon the pinions of the fleeting air,
And where dismounted? unto what great prince
Christian or pagan longs this mansion.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Are we in any sociable place?
Or in the cell of some magician,
Who by his skill in hellish exorcisms,
Made us his thrall?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I can forbear no longer,
Welcome thrice welcome.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Welcome?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Whence?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: To me.

sp.speaker: Ang. to us. Duke
sp.l: Thy father.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: And thy friends.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Do not beguile us, oh Demetrio?
We are betrayed, see the Magtiian,
That by his cunning and strong working charms,
Brought us unknown.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Into thy father's arms,
Welcome Emilia, with this ivory chain,
I sphere my hopes and in thy bosom rain,
These tears of comfort, then embrace thy friends.
Thy brother's art all further difference ends.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Your city.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Genoa ▪

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And your reverend name.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Ferneze.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Yes the very same,
I do remember when she went to nurse,
What a cursed vixen 'twas s, but now she's grown.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Not passed all goodness, yet I hope sir: but i'faith brother was't you that brought us from Turkey a cockhorse? and your Genoan hackney be so quick paced you shall have more of our custom.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Lay by discourse, what gentleman is that comes uninvited to our feast of joy.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.p: Pray welcome him father, he's a Genoan merchant, that with much suit ransomed me from the Turk.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: My hopes redeemer welcome, but proceed
Unto the doubtful fortunes of my child:
'Twas told me she was stolen from monta sancta.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You help my memory, thence she was stolen,
And for her beauty, chosen concubine
To the lascivious Turk, but by much suit,
And meditation of some special friends,
I bought her freedom with a thousand marks ▪

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Which we'll repay with ample interest,
Once more we'll bid you welcome, and to set
A smoother gloss upon our merriment,
There's a quick wench that only lives by wit,
Who understanding I had lost my daughter,
Borrowed thy habit, and usurps thy name,
One call her in, now daughter make thee sit,
To combat and dismount her active wit.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: A perilous girl, her wits a mere Snaphance,
Goes with a fire lock, she strikes fire from stones,
She knows the law too, a mere murdering piece,
sp.p: Fight low, lock close, she speaks mere ▪ lightning niece.

sp.speaker: Em
sp.p: How now father, have you put on your cōsidering cap, and bethought you? or shall I proceed and traverse my writ of errors?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.p: Ha, writ of errors? Law-tricks, words of art demurs and quillets.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: All not worth a pin, will you bethink you father?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I have bethought me, and to let thee see,
The true proportion of thy impudence,
Behold my daughter, whom thou personatest.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How, your daughter?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Yes minks, his daughter.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My niece, and I will make it good.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Pretty i'faith, have ye any more of these tricks? I may be outfaced of myself with a card often, but i'faith uncle, the best knave ith' bunch, nor all the law in your budget cannot do't, and as for you Sisley bumtrinkets, I'll have about with you at the single stackado are you a woman?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: A maid.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If his tongue falter, all our plots bewrayed.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: If a true maid, lend a true maid your hand.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Both hand and heart

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: The like of me command,
Now I conjure thee by the love
You bear Diane's friend grove,
By Cupid's bow , and go den arrow,
Venus' dove, and chirping sparrow,
By all those vo 〈…〉 es, the listening winds,
Hear when maids unclasp their minds.
By those sweet oaths men use in bed,
Besieging of a maiden head.
I do conjure you fore these lords,
To answer truly to my words.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: By these and more, by all the scapes
Of amorous Jove and Phoebus rapes,
By lover's sweet, and secret meetings,
Hand embracings and lip-greetings,
I promise you before these lords,
To answer truly to your words.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Where were you born?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: In Genoa.

sp.speaker: Em,
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Emilia.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Lie not.

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: 'Twere open shame
To lie before so many.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: In what art were you instructed?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: That's not in my part.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Say music.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Quickly ▪

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I was taught to sing,
Unto the lute, and court each amorous string
With a soft finger.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Good, how many springs
Lived you in monta santa?

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Zounds this stings.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How many?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Nine.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Zounds ten.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ten fops.

sp.speaker: Fm.
sp.l: Nay quick

sp.speaker: Joc.
sp.l: Twixt nine and ten ▪

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Right, answer.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'the nick.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Your age?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Em ▪
sp.l: Come, fie, you linger.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am just as old.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: As what?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: My little finger.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: You dally

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Sixteen.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Eighteen.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Eighteen fools,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Nay and you prompt we'll hiss you forth the schools.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Come your reply, nay quick your certain age,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I am just as old as — true Emila's page.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A page?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Disguised?

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Wrapped in a woman's smock?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I'm in a wood.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And I can spring a cock,

sp.speaker: In.
sp.l: Woodcock of our side:

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And you bill so fair,
Make a clear glade, I'll single forth a pair.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Fie her wit scalds.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: We shall have change of weather.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Cocks of one hen, come prince, let's hold together.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: I thought we should find a counterfeit of you

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Then nail me to your lips with a kiss, and make me currant payment.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What, young Orlando? how does charingcross?
Is Westminster yet friends with Winchester?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Zounds Julio now.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Alas my lord, it was a mere device to —

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Make your highness merry, when I heard
You were returned without your wished adventure.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: O master merchant, you adventured well,
To cheat yourself thus of a thousand marks,

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: How now my lord?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nay, I'll but see your breast, mine eyes desire,
no lower object.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Go to, read your errors.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: I cannot now return, non est inventa,
Brother embrace your child, your second heir,
I found firm witness in her bosom bare.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Art thou Emilia?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Emelia, your daughter, once a Turkish prisoner

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Receive a joyful blessing rise and say,
What wit or power freed thee.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.p: Dear father, the manner both of my enlarging and captiving I'll relate, when more convenient time and place shall incite me, but upon this occasion, pray give me leave to put my brother beside his melancholy

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I prithee do so.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Why how now student? grand magician,
Puritan, come, you never played the wag,
You know not Winefride's hem, nor the count's vault.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: A'mort man? what, can Polymetes daunt?
Hath 'a not hyren here?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Zounds all will out, brains —

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Now for a hundred dozen of larks to make a pie of the brains.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Well, done it was, and out it must.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why how now Polymetes in a dump?
Where's your Venetian merchant and your sister?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Who? Emilia? why look you here father, do you think I knew her not? ask the boy and Julio, do you think I would have maintained her as I did but only for affinities sake? what said I at first nuncle? did I not urge affinities? and you would see me hanged say and I did not urge affinity?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And yet you pleaded hard for a night's lodging

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.p: Only to try thy honesty by this element, ask my uncle else?

div.stage: Enter Horatio's page and whisper with Polimetes.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: He's a sweet womanist.

sp.speaker: Lur,
sp.l: No more a that, niece you're a wag.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Well said old water rat,
But that my brother conjurer should fail,
In the black art. —

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the black pudding: pish,
Of all arts else, only the law is firm.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: And yet that danceth changes every term.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: Well jest on gallants, and uncle, you that make a pish at the black art, my books to the piece of arras, where Venus and Adonis stood kissing and the cuckoldly pandar Vulcan watched them, and all your by ways to boot, I raise up my aunt your late wife in the same proportion, habit and gesture, she usually wore in her life time.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Do that, I'll swear there's virtue in thy art.

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.p: And if I do not, say philosophy is foolery, logic legerdemain, and conjuring mere cony-catching, as indeed it is.
sp.l: And now by virtue of this wand,
Each in his circle keep his stand,
Now Belioll and Astaroth,
Sole commanders of the North,
By Hecate's head, Erinnis' snakes,
Styx and all infernal lakes,
I charge you kneel to Proserpine,
And by her licence all divine
Dismiss the countess from those shades,
Where pleasure springs and never fades.
Festina, cito, citius, come
Free tenant of Elysium.

div.stage: Enter countess, she writes a little, throws down the paper and departs.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The count look, pale.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why starts Horatio?

sp.speaker: Lu. ▪
sp.l: What written the shadow?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: That, these lines will show,
Horatio, base Horatio poisoned me,
I was your sister, right mine injury.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Horatio?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yes, Horatio poisoned her
Revenge it Duke be a true justicer.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Revenged I will, degenerous homicide,
What reason led thee to so damned a deed?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I loved her, wood her, my hot love denied
Change into hate, I poisoned her, she died.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sounds this like truth.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: And if you think I lie,
Ask Lurdo, his damned tongue will answer I.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Had he a hand in't?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: No, I will demur.

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Revenge it Duke, be a true justicer.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: He gave the poison.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And you laid the plot

sp.speaker: Ad.
sp.l: Knit up two villains in one riding knot.

sp.speaker: Poly.
sp.l: What quillet now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: At non plus.

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Senseless, mute?
Silence cries guilty, a lets fall the suit.

sp.speaker: Lur. Hor.
sp.l: Our sentence guilty,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Then be this your doom,
You shall be closed alone in her dead tomb.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Urge a reprieve:

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Our punishment defer,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: No, we must be an upright justicer;
To the execution.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do, the world shall prove
My heart's as bold to die as 'twas to love.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: By’r lady so is not mine, I'd give my goods,
For a good habeas Corpus, to remove me
Into another country.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Leave demurs,
Close them into that grave, that dead man's inn,
pity true virtue should be lodged with sin.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Make room dear madam, law this leave doth give
To die by thee with whom I could not live,

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: And wronged countess though I hated thee,
I come to take my latest sleep with thee.

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Kind thou art welcome, and shalt ever have,
My arms thy winding sheet, my breast thy grave.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sister?

sp.speaker: Po.
sp.l: Aunt?

sp.speaker: Em.
sp.l: Madam?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: My much wronged wife?

sp.speaker: Count
sp.l: Justice great Duke, give me my husband's life,
Both his and his, if your demand be why,
See she survives for whose death they should die.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Alive.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Unblemished.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Sblood I gave her poison.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I could tell your honour a tale in your ear to the contrary, I must needs say your will was good, but my father being your drug-seller, instead of a deadly poison, gave you a sleepy potion, do you remember the echo at the tomb? though I played the knave with you, I did like an honest man with her.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Thou did indeed, and I'll requite thee well.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How now uncle? what think you of scholarship now?

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: As of the law, good as it may be used,
But to my wife.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Brother, I'll speak your part,
Receive her, love, and lodge her in your heart.

sp.speaker: Lur.
sp.l: Nocte dieque.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What shall I do then?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Justice shall merce thee, and by our command
We banish thee the court, though not our land,
Your course is virtuous, let your honour grow
Till age hath clothed you in a robe of snow.
Lastly, thy merit is not trivial,
That turned to mirth a scene so tragical.

lg.l: Who would have thought, such strange events should fall
Into a course so smooth and comical?
Who would have thought such treachery could rest,
In such a smooth and virtuous seeming breast?
Who would have thought a bud of this young growth,
Should out of present wit o'erreach us both?
And to conclude, who would have thought the ear
Of your mild patience would so gently bear
With these our weak deserts? which if they please you ought
'Tis less than we desire, more than we thought.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
